title: BBC will launch smart-speaker news service allowing users to skip stories they're not interested in
text:
If you're fed up with hearing about Brexit on every bulletin, here's some good news.

The BBC is to launch the UK's first interactive voice news service allowing smart-speaker users to skip stories they are not interested in.

Owners of Alexa-enabled devices, from today, can say to their speaker 'Give me BBC News' and tailor the news to suit their interests.

This will also allow them to ask for more information about news they are keen on hearing about, including extended interviews and features, specially commissioned items, as well as archive material.

Owners of Alexa-enabled devices, from today, can say to their speaker 'Give me BBC News' and tailor the news to suit their interests

At the moment the BBC offers Alexa users a 'straightforward' radio-like bulletin. But the corporation says the new service will let people get 'closer to the stories that matter to them' and let people access news in a way that suits them.

Mukul Devichand, executive editor for BBC Voice and AI, said: 'Smart speakers give us the chance to re-imagine what radio would be like if it were invented today, free from its technical limitations.

The service will be available on devices using Amazon's Alexa voice assistant. The BBC is looking to launch it on other platforms soon (file image)

'By making the news interactive on smart speakers, listeners can jump to the stories they need to hear just before rushing out of the house, or, when they have more time, they can delve into a piece and find out more.'

The service will be available on devices using Amazon's Alexa voice assistant. The BBC is looking to launch it on other platforms soon.
